poster_metadata.display_title:
South America's Gifts:
From Earth’s Treasure to Human Spirit

map_asset.description: Stylized South America country map with per-country fill colors and major river lines; includes labels for several countries.

palette_by_country.notes: French Guiana appears on the proof map but is not listed in the XLSX palette.

legend.title:
SOUTH AMERICA
HIGH AND LOW LEGEND

rules.default_good_marker: green icon with '+' badge indicates a positive/high (or otherwise desirable) exemplar
rules.default_bad_marker: orange/red icon with '−' badge indicates a negative/low (or otherwise undesirable) exemplar

exception_notes.exception: For crime, the 'good' exemplar is the lowest crime rate (low is good), so the green '+' corresponds to lower crime.
Household size uses color-coded icons (purple vs blue) without +/- badges; interpreted as largest vs smallest rather than good/bad.

directionality.notes: Displayed as largest vs smallest household size, not explicitly good/bad on the legend (no +/- badges).

core_stats_available_not_displayed.highest_countries_values_raw: Highest: Brazil (Carnival, rich musical traditions), Colombia (vibrant cultural scene)
core_stats_available_not_displayed.lowest_countries_values_raw: Lowest: Suriname, Guyana (limited formal participation, though tradition persists)

low_exemplars.value_text: limited formal participation, though tradition persists

core_stats_available_not_displayed.notes: Present in the XLSX 'Interesting Statistics' table but not shown in the proof poster's High/Low legend.

continent_stats_map.notes: Core stats list derived from the proof legend; exemplars/values derived ONLY from the XLSX 'Interesting Statistics' table.

featurettes.title: Powering the Future—South America's Lithium Triangle
featurettes.body_text:
High in the sun-baked deserts where Argentina, Bolivia, and Chile meet, pale salt flats
sparkle like mirrors. Beneath these dazzling plains lies something precious—lithium, a
metal essential for the batteries that power our phones, cars, and even the future of clean
energy. This region, known as the “Lithium Triangle,” holds more than half of the world’s
known lithium reserves.

As electric vehicles and solar panels become common, the demand for lithium grows.
Mining it can bring jobs and prosperity to local communities, yet it also raises tough
questions. Extracting lithium uses lots of water and may affect nearby plants, animals,
and indigenous peoples who have cared for this land for centuries. By working together—
governments, businesses, and local communities—South America’s lithium-rich deserts
can help shape a cleaner, greener tomorrow, without losing the natural and cultural
treasures that make these places so special.

assets.description: White salt flats under a bright blue sky (hero image for Lithium Triangle featurette).
Inset map highlighting the Lithium Triangle across Argentina, Bolivia, and Chile.
Diagram showing lithium extraction from brine: extraction, pumping, solar evaporation ponds, and lithium carbonate plant.

chart_spec.layout_notes: Left-to-right flow with icons and labeled steps (extraction of brine → pumping → evaporation ponds → processing plant).

featurettes.notes: Body text and title transcribed from the proof poster.

featurettes.title:
One Continent, Two Languages—
Spanish and Portuguese in
South America
featurettes.body_text:
If you look at a map of South America, you’ll find most countries
speaking Spanish, while Brazil—the largest country—speaks Portuguese. This language
divide began centuries ago when Spain and Portugal carved up new lands during the Age
of Exploration. A special line called the Treaty of Tordesillas gave Portugal control of what
is now Brazil, and Spain colonized much of the rest.

As a result, flavors of language, music, and dance flowed into these lands, mixing with the
voices of indigenous peoples who have lived here for thousands of years. Today, from
samba in Brazil to tango in Argentina, these traditions blend European words and rhythms
with native sounds and stories. While Spanish and Portuguese dominate, hundreds of
Indigenous languages still echo through rainforests and mountain villages, reminding us
that South America’s true beauty lies in its rich tapestry of voices.

assets.description: Map showing where Spanish and Portuguese are spoken (Romance languages distribution reference).
Argentine tango performers (Spanish-speaking cultural example). Not visibly used on the proof poster, but included as a linked option in the Featurettes.docx.
Illustration: Romance languages family tree with Spanish and Portuguese as close relatives.

chart_spec.layout_notes: Tree graphic titled 'ROMANCE LANGUAGES' with labeled branches (e.g., Italian, Spanish, Portuguese, French, Vulgar Latin).

assets.notes: No explicit source URL found in provided docs for the tree illustration.

featurettes.notes: Body text and title transcribed from the proof poster.

featurettes.title:
Feeding the World
—South America’s Role
in Global Food Trade
featurettes.body_text:
Have you ever tasted fresh grapes in winter, or savored coffee from
far-off fields? South America is a food powerhouse, shipping fruits,
grains, and coffee beans across oceans so that people everywhere
can enjoy them all year long. Brazil’s coffee might end up in your
morning cup, Chilean grapes could sweeten your afternoon snack, and
Ecuadorian bananas may appear in your fruit bowl—even if it’s snowy outside your window.

This global trade supports farmers, builds roads and ports, and brings
distant cultures closer together. But it also comes with challenges. Clearing
forests for farmland may harm wildlife, and shipping food around the globe
adds pollution. As more people demand these tasty treats, farmers, traders,
and governments must find ways to grow crops sustainably, protect the
environment, and ensure fair treatment for the hands that plant, harvest,
and deliver our food tracing food from field to store.

assets.description: Rows of coffee plants on a hillside farm (used as header photo for Food Trade featurette).
Map showing major export crops by country with labeled callouts (e.g., COCOA, BANANAS, CORN, YERBA MATE, ORANGES, SUGARCANE, GRAPES).

chart_spec.layout_notes: Small South America silhouette with crop icons and label tags placed near producing countries.
chart_spec.iconization_rules: One primary crop label per country (callout).

assets.description: Vertical 'FARM-TO-TABLE' flowchart: FIELD → TABLE with simple icons.

chart_spec.layout_notes: Stacked icons and labels aligned vertically, left of the featurette body text.

featurettes.notes: Body text and title transcribed from the proof poster.

featurettes.title:
Tourism
Transforming Communities
—The Impact of Visitors
featurettes.body_text:
From the ancient stone city of Machu Picchu perched high in Peru’s
Andes to the thundering falls of Iguazu, South America’s wonders
draw travelers from all over the world. These visitors bring money,
helping pay for schools, hospitals, and better roads. They also learn
about local traditions, celebrating colorful festivals and tasting foods
that reflect centuries of culture.

But tourism can also bring problems. Too many people can wear
down fragile ruins, disturb wildlife, or fill quiet towns with
traffic and trash. Local residents must find a balance—welcoming
guests while preserving the natural and cultural treasures that
made these places special in the first place. By choosing
sustainable tours, respecting local rules, and listening to the
voices of community leaders, visitors can help ensure that
tourism helps rather than harms, leaving a legacy that future
generations can enjoy.

assets.description: Machu Picchu’s terraces against a mountainous backdrop (hero image).
Busy marketplace / tourist town scene (supporting image).
assets.notes: Multiple linked photo options are provided in the Featurettes.docx for this single line item.

assets.description: Infographic showing tourism revenue from visitors flowing into investment in communities (education, healthcare, infrastructure).

chart_spec.layout_notes: Right-column vertical flow: TOURISM (suitcase) → REVENUE FROM VISITORS → INVESTMENT IN COMMUNITIES branching to EDUCATION / HEALTHCARE / INFRASTRUCTURE.
chart_spec.iconization_rules: Icons with arrows; no numeric values shown in proof.

featurettes.notes: Body text and title transcribed from the proof poster.

supplemental_stats_for_app.title: Glacial Water Dependency
supplemental_stats_for_app.description: Andean countries depend on glacial meltwater for freshwater supply, making them vulnerable to glacial retreat driven by climate change.

supplemental_stats_for_app.title: Beef Consumption
supplemental_stats_for_app.description: Argentina is among the highest per-capita beef consumers globally (≈55 kg per person annually), reflecting cultural importance of beef in the diet.

supplemental_stats_for_app.title: Amazon Rainforest Deforestation
supplemental_stats_for_app.description: Brazil has significant deforestation pressures in the Amazon, affecting environmental safety, Indigenous communities, and global climate.

notes: Featurette titles/body text were transcribed from the proof poster image; docx copy was used primarily for hyperlink extraction and asset sourcing.
Core stat exemplars were extracted ONLY from the 'Interesting Statistics' table in the XLSX, then matched to the stats listed on the proof legend.
